speaker: grahampaige
content: Welcome everyone. Let's begin discussion on: Agenda Item No. 3.4: Student Code of Conduct - The board will review proposed updates to the district’s Student Code of Conduct, which outlines behavioral expectations and disciplinary procedures. Key changes include new rules around cell phone usage during instructional time, updates to the dress code to reflect inclusivity and professionalism, and revisions to disciplinary consequences to promote restorative practices.. Who would like to start?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content:
I'll go first. Thank you Graham. As we consider these important policy updates today, let us keep our focus squarely where it belongs – on students' well-being, equity, and academic success. We must ensure that any policies support all learners equally while fostering a safe environment conducive to learning. So what are some key highlights from staff regarding the updated discipline procedure recommendations?
```nameTag is grahampaige (Assistant Superintendent) ```

speaker: grahampaige
content:
Dr. Alcarez has been working with his team diligently over several months now. They have developed an approach centered upon student-centeredness, cultural sensitivity, social-emotional growth, trauma-informed care, family engagement, as well as teacher training and development opportunities. It also includes more robust data collection tools so they can better track incidents by race, ethnicity, gender identity, sexual orientation, disability status, English language learner designation, socioeconomic background, grade level, school site location, incident type, consequence assigned, whether there was parental contact made, if law enforcement were involved, among other factors. And then finally, he wants to make sure that teachers receive ongoing coaching through their PLCs about how best to implement culturally responsive teaching strategies within each classroom setting. This way, educators feel empowered when addressing misbehavior without escalating situations further into formal infractions whenever possible., but still maintaining clear boundaries necessary for orderliness inside classrooms. He'd be happy to answer questions later after Kate Acuff shares her thoughts too. Ms. Coughlin-Acuff?, do you want to add anything else before opening up Q&A session?. 
```
kateacuff: Yes, thank you very much Mr. Page. Good evening everybody. My name is Kate Akufa Assistant Director Equity Excellence Division. What my colleague said really resonated deeply because one thing that came out loud and clearly throughout every single stakeholder group meeting was just how critical relationships between adults at schools matter. Students need positive connections with caring supportive people who believe them capable of achieving great things no matter circumstances outside those walls may look like. Our goal here should always center around creating environments grounded firmly in love empathy compassion understanding mutual trust along lines of shared humanity rather than fear punishment control compliance obedience authority figures above others. One major area needing improvement right away involves giving kids voice agency autonomy self-determination especially concerning matters directly impacting themselves most closely such as personal appearance clothing choices digital citizenship rights privacy safety security online presence appropriate use technology devices responsibly respecting peers differences backgrounds values beliefs perspectives cultures identities lifestyles experiences talents abilities strengths challenges needs interests passions hopes dreams fears concerns goals aspirations futures lives stories histories families communities neighborhoods cities counties states nations world history present future past everything intertwined connected interdependent interconnected global citizens living together peacefully harmoniously respectfully equitably fairly collaboratively cooperatively productively fruitfully happily joyously lovingly sustainably long-term holistically systemically structurally foundationally transformationally progressively positively proactively reactively responsively immediately effectively efficiently urgently seriously sincerely mindfully thoughtfully carefully

speaker: katrinacallsen
content:
Thanks both Jon Noel Carro and Katie Acoff for your comments tonight. There seems to be quite a bit going forward with respect to updating the conduct codes across multiple areas including cellphone utilization, attire guidelines, penalties associated with misconduct, plus incorporating healing methods towards conflict resolution. Can someone explain why certain items moved down lower priority levels? For instance, under item number three point two subpoint B, 'Student Expectations', the original draft had mentioned something related to hate speech being added explicitly; however, looking closer at the revised version submitted last week does not seem to contain explicit mention anymore. Was there specific feedback received causing its removal or did committee members decide against pursuing inclusion following discussions held since September meetings started taking place back again.?  
```roleholdernothingnothing nothing nothing nothing nothing nothing nothing nothing nothing nothing nothing nothing nothing nothing nothing nothing nothing nothing 

speaker: davidoberg
content: I appreciate Katrina's question regarding the omission of "hate speech" from our updated code revisions. To clarify, we didn't remove it due to lack of importance, but instead chose to integrate these aspects into broader categories focusing on bullying, harassment, discrimination, and disrespect toward individuals based on protected characteristics. We wanted to ensure comprehensive coverage while avoiding redundancy. If anyone would like me to elaborate during the Q&A section, please don't hesitate to ask. Now, are there any additional points or queries prior to moving ahead with discussion and potential adjustments?

speaker: judyle
content: Thank you David Oberg for clarifying the reasoning behind omitting "hate speech." It makes sense to incorporate it into more encompassing sections dealing with bullying, harassment, etcetera. As an aside, could we also consider adding language emphasizing education and awareness surrounding microaggressions alongside restorative practices implementation? By doing so, students can better understand impact beyond intent, fostering healthier interactions among diverse groups. Would welcome input on feasibility and suggestions.

speaker: kateacuff
content: Judy Le, excellent suggestion about integrating educational components addressing microagressions within restorative practice implementations! speaker: judyle
content: Kate Cuff, thank you for your enthusiasm and support for incorporating educational elements focused on microaggressions within restorative practices. Your eloquent expression highlights the significance of creating a culture that values empathy, inclusivity, and mutual respect. Let us indeed strive towards cultivating such environments where every individual feels not only tolerated but truly belonged. Shall we now discuss how best to implement these measures effectively across various grade levels and student demographics? Perhaps Ellen Osborne has some insights to share given her experience working closely with teachers and administrators.

speaker: ellenosborne
content: Absolutely, Judy Le. Implementing effective strategies requires collaboration between educators, administration, and community stakeholders. Research suggests tiered approaches tailored to specific age ranges and demographic needs yield optimal results. For instance, elementary schools might focus on social-emotional skill-building through storytelling and role-playing, whereas high schools may benefit from peer-led workshops exploring nuanced topics like implicit bias and intersectionality. What do others think? How have similar initiatives worked in their respective settings?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Thanks, Ellen Osborne. That sounds very reasonable considering different developmental stages require distinct methods. One thing worth noting is ensuring consistency throughout each level by establishing clear expectations communicated clearly via teacher training sessions as well as parent engagement opportunities. Additionally, perhaps we should explore ways to involve local organizations specializing in diversity equity inclusion work who offer expertise facilitating discussions around sensitive subjects. Their involvement will help foster trust amongst families feeling historically marginalized. Does anybody know if those partnerships already exist here locally? And what other thoughts does everyone else have concerning engaging parents guardians caregivers family members at large?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: I appreciate Jon Alcaro's emphasis on involving external experts familiar with DEI issues when implementing our new policies. speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Katrina Callsen, thanks so much for sharing all those connections; it seems there are many valuable assets available right away. It would be wise then to tap into them strategically while also being mindful about avoiding overreliance upon any one organization. We must ensure diverse perspectives inform policy implementation. As an aside, Graham Page mentioned earlier today something which resonates deeply – fostering growth mindsets among students staff alike remains crucial amidst change efforts. By doing so, collective resilience increases allowing more successful navigation during challenging times ahead. David Oberg had expressed concerns previously surrounding disciplinary procedure revisions' potential impact on school climate overall. Would he kindly elaborate further please since time constraints didn't allow him sufficient opportunity before lunch break ended? His input could prove invaluable moving forward.

speaker: davidoberg
content: Thank you, Jon Alcaro, for bringing up my previous concern. Indeed, revisiting disciplinary procedures can significantly influence school atmosphere. My apprehension stems from potentially unintended consequences affecting certain student populations disproportionately. Therefore, I propose integrating data analysis tracking instances of misconduct alongside corresponding responses to identify trends indicating systemic biases. This information enables targeted adjustments promoting fairness without compromising accountability. Furthermore, let’s consider piloting alternatives focusing on rehabilitation rather than punishment alone. Such holistic approach fosters healthier learning spaces benefiting both individuals involved directly and indirectly. Any suggestions on feasible metrics for monitoring progress toward equitable outcomes?

speaker: judyle
content: Data collection and analysis are essential steps towards identifying patterns that perpetuate inequities within our current system. The proposed pilot program offers a promising avenue for exploration. Perhaps we could establish key performance indicators (KPIs) such as reduction in suspensions/expulsions rates, increased attendance, improved grades, enhanced self-reported feelings of safety, etc., to gauge effectiveness. These KPIs serve not only evaluation purposes but provide actionable insights guiding future refinements. Kate Cuff, your experience working closely with various departments has given me confidence in asking how these measures align with district goals set forth last year. Could you enlighten us on whether alignment exists and suggest possible areas where adaptations need occur?

speaker: kateacuff
content: Yes Judy Le, indeed some overlap between suggested KPIs and established objectives is present. For instance, reducing suspension and expulsion numbers ties back to Goal Three emphasizing safe inclusive environments. However, refining specific targets may necessitate collaboration across multiple teams ensuring seamless integration throughout the entire process. One area warranting adaptation involves incorporating restorative practices training for teachers administrators support personnel addressing implicit bias recognition strategies along with providing ongoing coaching feedback mechanisms supporting educators grappling with complex situations requiring nuanced approaches balancing empathy firmness consistency compassion understanding individualized needs. What do others think might facilitate smoother transitions embracing updated code components?

speaker: ellenosborne
content: Excellent discussion thus far! To build upon Kate's suggestion, I recommend establishing a dedicated task force comprising representatives from each department to oversee the integration of revised policies and ensure consistent messaging. Additionally, regular check-ins and progress updates will help maintain momentum and address emerging challenges promptly. How does everyone feel about setting quarterly review sessions to assess our collective effort towards creating a fairer, more supportive environment?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Ellen Osborne, excellent idea regarding formation of interdepartmental task forces coupled with scheduled reviews every quarter. That structure promotes cohesion transparency around new initiatives ultimately enhancing their chances at success. Quarterly assessments enable timely course corrections if necessary keeping stakeholders informed plus maintaining focus amid competing priorities. Now considering teacher administrator professional development opportunities tied explicitly to discipline reform should remain high priority too because they're pivotal catalysts driving meaningful shifts inside classrooms hallways beyond. speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Thanks so much, John Alcaro, David O'Berg, Judy Le, Kate Acuff, and Ellen Osborn for all those thoughtful comments. It sounds like there was quite an array of ideas presented during today's session ranging from implementing alternative forms of discipline focused on restoration over punitive means through collecting relevant statistics capturing potential disparities down to even staff preparation via specialized courses centered around topics including managing conflicts peacefully resolving disputes respectfully while also being cognizant of diverse backgrounds cultures identities et cetera. And then finally, it seems people were discussing ways by which schools would be held responsible for adhering to any newly adopted guidelines perhaps using regularly occurring evaluations conducted once per academic term. So just wanted to summarize what appears to be general agreement among attendees here now. Is anything missing crucially important needing immediate attention right away? Or shall we move ahead into next week when hopefully finalizing plans for policy changes become clearer following additional research consultation community stakeholder involvement board approval ratifying votes. We'll make sure minutes accurately reflect everything discussed thoroughly later tonight posting them publicly tomorrow afternoon. If no one else wishes to contribute currently, thank you again everybody who participated actively engaging thoughtfully contributing meaningfully making valuable points worth serious consideration going forward. Stay tuned until Wednesday night unless otherwise notified differently thanks very much. Goodnight.

speaker: davidoberg
content: Thank you, Katrina Callsen, for that thorough summary. Before adjourning, let me emphasize my enthusiasm for these collaborative efforts toward fostering safer, more equitable spaces within our school system. The suggestions made are truly commendable; however, as Jon mentioned earlier, effective implementation hinges significantly on comprehensive educator training focusing not only on disciplinary procedures but also essential skills such as conflict resolution, unconscious biases, and student-centered approachability. This commitment must extend past initial rollouts, encompassing continuous evaluation refinement adjustments tailored to evolving concerns unique to various demographics represented within our communities. As Ellen proposed, dedicating time slots for cross-functional committee work alongside structured follow-up assessments ensures accountability adaptability moving forward. Let’s continue striving collectively for systemic change grounded firmly in fairness respect mutual trust. Until next week stay engaged committed.

speaker: judyle
content: I appreciate your sentiments, David, and couldn't agree more on the importance of sustained support for educators throughout this process. To build upon that point, I suggest exploring partnerships with local organizations specializing in restorative practices, implicit bias recognition, and trauma-sensitive approaches to provide ongoing coaching and resources for teachers and administrators alike. By doing so, we can foster a deeper understanding of the complexities surrounding equity-focused reforms and create lasting impact across our entire district.

speaker: davidoberg
content: Absolutely, Judy! Your suggestion is spot-on regarding strategic collaborations with experts offering targeted expertise. Such alliances will undoubtedly enhance capacity-building measures ensuring long-term efficacy of implemented policies. Additionally, consider inviting representatives from partnering entities onto our task force providing invaluable insights further enrichening discourse decision-making processes. Their input could prove instrumental refining strategies addressing specific needs emerging from data analysis thus far.

speaker: judyle
content: That's a great idea, David. Incorporating external stakeholders' perspectives will indeed strengthen our collective effort towards creating meaningful reform. Furthermore, their participation may facilitate access to existing best-practice models, allowing us to learn from successful implementations elsewhere and avoid duplicative efforts.

speaker: davidoberg
content: Exactly, Judy! Leveraging outside knowledge enables informed adaptation rather than reinventing wheels. Moreover, having partners invested in our success fosters opportunities for resource sharing potentially offsetting costs associated with professional development initiatives. These synergies ultimately benefit both parties involved – enhancing outcomes locally while advancing broader regional progress toward inclusive environments promoting holistic student wellness.

speaker: kateacuff
content:
Agree wholeheartedly about incorporating expert voices and leveraging established networks to inform our decisions. Another key aspect lies in establishing clear communication channels between administration, faculty members, students, parents/guardians, and other critical stakeholders to ensure seamless dissemination of information updates related to revised code enforcement mechanisms. What steps should we take initially to guarantee transparent messaging consistency across platforms avoiding confusion misinterpretation misinformation spreading rapidly especially considering varying levels language proficiency cultural familiarity technological comfort amongst constituents served?
```

speaker: ellenosborne
content: Excellent question, Kate. Establishing open lines of communication is vital to the success of these reforms. Initially, I recommend forming a dedicated communications subcommittee comprising representatives from each stakeholder group to develop a multi-faceted strategy for disseminating accurate, accessible information through varied mediums (e.g., website updates, social media, newsletters, town hall meetings). This team can also oversee translation services and accommodate different literacy levels to cater to our linguistically and culturally diverse population. Transparency and clarity will help alleviate misconceptions and promote buy-in from everyone affected by these policy revisions.

speaker: kateacuff
content: Great proposal, Ellen. A well-represented comms subgroup guarantees sensitivity awareness concerning nuances inherent to distinct constituent groups facilitating broad comprehension acceptance. Would anyone object if we scheduled its first meeting immediately after spring break giving ample opportunity beforehand reviewing notes reflecting discussions had up till date plus conducting preliminary outreach identifying ideal candidates filling roles inside respective committees? Also how do others feel about setting aside some portion regular sessions specifically allocated solely discussion questions arising out of new developments since last gathering maintaining momentum staying updated collaboratively?

speaker: grahampaige
content: Thank you everyone for voting. After counting all the votes, we have 7 (public) / 6 (private) in favor, 0 (public) / 0 (private) against, and 0 (public) / 1 (private) abstaining. Results → Public: approved, Private: approved, Combined: approved. Thank you everyone for coming, have a nice night.
